posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: After viewing a log file and the amount of variation in the voltage as the robot is put through it’s paces, I am starting to wonder if a better starting point for critical systems shoudn’t be PeakForwardVoltage = 11.0;  or even 10.5.

posts.name: Andy Mundell
posts.cooked:
Great question. I’m interested to hear what the really knowledgeable people have to say about it. My instincts are that most mechanisms aren’t using their maximum power anyways, so this could result in more consistent (albeit slower) behavior in those mechanisms. In the past, we might have just thrown a smaller motor at these mechanisms, but perhaps a voltage limited big motor could be a better choice.

What would be the net effect if teams did this and then increased the current limits on those motors to an equivalent power output? More consistent performance with a lower top speed? Or will this just lead to larger voltage drops as teams pull more and more amps, negating any benefits?

Following.

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
We’ve set this at 11V for the past couple years with a similar line of thinking. I believe every motor is set there

I don’t think we’ve done any real testing to see if this helps. Very interested to hear what other teams do and if this is actually the best approach.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: I get doing this for something that needs close following and has motor power to spare (like an arm or elevator). But for mechanisms where you want every bit of power possible and don’t need perfect following (like a drivetrain or flywheel), lowering the max voltage seems like it’s just limiting the max power of the system for no real gain.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
When your controls output is saturated, you cannot reject disturbances.

If you want nice controls, don’t saturate.

If you don’t care about nice controls, saturate all you want.

There is no free lunch.

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked:
One of the thoughts I was considering was our current shooter.  If it is calibrated for a certain RPM , how often are you NOT achieving that RPM ?

Google Drive file.
